description: From New Latin autopsia, from Ancient Greek αὐτοψῐ́ᾱ (autopsíā, “seeing with one's own eyes”).

entries.meaning: A dissection performed on a cadaver to find possible cause(s) of death.
examples: The autopsy revealed he had died of multiple bullet wounds.

entries.meaning: An after-the-fact examination, especially of the causes of a failure.
examples: This lack of built-in clutter makes the system easy to comprehend. Debugging facilities are few but powerful: snapshots, tracing, and autopsy.

entries.meaning: (rare) An eyewitness observation, the presentation of an event as witnessed.

verbs.description: autopsy (third-person singular simple present autopsies, present participle autopsying, simple past and past participle autopsied)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To perform an after-the-fact analysis of, especially of a failure.
examples: The user may define his own errors, and use DUMPAL to autopsy the system for him.
